6 Minute English
From BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Sophie…
speaker: Sophie

text: Neil?
Neil?
Oh, sorry! … And I'm Neil.
speaker: Neil

text: Neil, please put down your phone. We're doing the show!
speaker: Sophie

text: Yeah, I know. Hang on a minute. I just need to tweet something and… Done!
speaker: Neil

text: Done.
And the subject to today's show is social media and it's impact on our daily lives.
Ah, well, I suppose it has had quite a big impact on mine.
That's all too clear. Now, perhaps we can move on to today's quiz question?
speaker: Sophie

text: Of course. I'm all ears. Oh, hang on. Wait a second.
There's a word to describe what you're doing, you know. Answer me this.
OK. I asked: Which word describes a situation where you're talking to someone and they suddenly look down at their phone or answer it? Is it…a) phobbing? b) phibbing? Or c) phubbing?
speaker: Sophie

text: at their phone or answer it? Is it a, fobbing, b, fibbing, or c, fubbing?
Well, you've got me there, Sophie. I have no idea, but I'll guess that it's c, fubbing.
Well, we'll find out later on in the show whether you've got the answer right or not.
Now, let's move on and talk about phone etiquette.
etiquette means rules of polite behaviour in society or among people in a certain group.
Well… interrupting conversations to check your phone has become a social norm, hasn't it, Sophie?
speaker: Neil

text: Social norms are the rules of behaviour considered acceptable in a group or society.
I don't agree, Neil. Let's listen to Professor Sherry Terkel of the Massachusetts
Institute of Technology talking about social norms amongst students.
I interviewed hundreds of college students and what they talked about was what some of them
called the rule of three and what the rule of three is, which is that if you go to dinner with
friends, you don't want to look down at your phone until you see that three people, let's say,
your six at dinner, are looking up in the conversation. So there's a new etiquette where you don't
look down unless three people are looking up kind of to keep the little conversation alive.
Why don't you try out the rule of three once in a while?
speaker: Sophie

text: There are only two of us here, Sophie - do the math! And I'm listening to you… mmm… let me just send a text message here on my phone ... hang on…
speaker: Neil

text: Let me just send a text message there here on my phone. Hang on.
Neil… NEIL! I'm not going to carry on with the show unless you pay attention!
speaker: Sophie

text: Sorry, Sophie. Actually I was just doing that to wind you up. I wasn't really using my phone… Sorry.
speaker: Neil

text: And to wind someone up means to say or do something deliberately in order to annoy someone.
Well, I do get wind up about people constantly checking their devices.
Yesterday, I was in a cafe and two girls came in. They sat down and started chatting away.
But not to each other, they were tapping away on their devices. And there was no face-to-face
But you can have moments of connection using your devices, you know?
speaker: Neil

text: If you have a connection with someone you engage emotionally.
speaker: connection

text: morning and there were a couple sharing a tablet. They were looking at the screen and talking about
what they saw there. It was very intimate and they were well, very connected. Let's hear from
Ian Sinclair, British poet and filmmaker, talking about a new generation of connected humans.
Physiologically, we're changing. That almost the neck muscles are tipped over.
They look down. We're getting a new kind of human being and I think maybe I'm not getting it,
that there is actually a different kind of intimacy emerging in which these instruments are very
important. So, Ian Sinclair says our physiology is changing. Our bodies, our neck muscles are changing,
to make it easier to look down all the time at our devices. But it isn't only muscles that might
change as a result of our techie habits. It's the way we interact or engage with each other too.
Ian Sinclair talks about a different kind of intimacy emerging. What does he mean, Neil?
Our intimacy or closeness with other people is somehow connected up with our devices.
They've become part of us and I expect someday devices will literally be part of us and implant
in our neck or something. Oh, what a horrible thought. Let's have the quiz question again,
Sophie, to take your mind off it. Okay. I asked, which word describes a situation where you are
talking to someone and they suddenly look down at their phone or answer it? Is it A, fobbing,
B, fibbing or C, fobbing? And I said C, fobbing. You were right, Neil. Well done. It's a combination
of phone and snubbing. Snub means to deliberately ignore someone you know. New words formed by
putting together parts of existing words are known as blends or portmante words. And fobbing is
starting to appear in some online dictionaries. Now, can we hear the words we learnt today, Neil?
Neil? Okay, I'll say the words myself. Etiquette. Wind someone up. Have a connection with someone.
Physiology. Interact. Intimacy. Snub. Well, that's the end of today's six minute English.
Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Don't forget to connect with us again soon! Come on Neil, connect with us! Come on!
speaker: Sophie

text: Oh yeah, hang on. Just got to, uh, goodbye. Hang on. I'll be with you in a second.
Yes. Okay. Bye.
